document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Megaphyllum projectum Verhoeff species complex (Myriapoda: Diplopoda: Julida: Julidae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–7. (1) In situ gonopods of a
M. p. projectum
male, from ANP, Hungary, caudal view. (2) Right promere of a
M. p . projectum
individual, from ANP, Hungary, mesal view. (3) Right opisthomere of the same individual, lateral view (scale bars: 0.5 mm). (4) Same individual, apical end of left opisthomere, mesal view (scale bar: 0.1 mm). Right opishomere of the same individual (5) caudo-lateral view; (6) lateral view; (7) antero-lateral view (scale bars: 0.2 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Females 30 –51.9 mm long, 2.6–4.2 mm high, with ( 42 + 1 +T)–( 49 + 1 +T) segments, adult females varied between the developmental stadia XI–XIII. Overall body colour variable, mainly brownish with a black longitudinal line dorsally, surrounded by two yellowish lines. Female genitalia: two big ampullas, the dorsal wide, bulbous one joining the elongated, well-developed ventral one by a long spiral apodemic tube (
Fig. 8
a–c). Vulval chaetotaxy not clear, all vulval parts bear randomly arranged setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
M. p. projectum
genitalia variation: (a)–(c) female vulvae, (d)–(i) males, right and left opisthomeres from mesal view. (a) ANP, Szin, Szelcepuszta, left vulva caudal, right vulva mesal view; (b) ANP, Jósvafő, Tohonya Valley, left vulva caudal, right vulva mesal view; (c) Romania, Maramureşului Basin, Rona de Sus, left vulva caudal, right vulva anterior view. (d)–(h) five males from the same vial, ANP, Aggtelek, Ménes valley. (i) ANP, Aggtelek, Patkós Valley (scale bars: 0.2 mm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Different levels of within-population variability of male gonopods were found: ( 1 ) differences of the same opisthomere due to changing its orientation under microscope (
Figs. 5–7
), ( 2 ) differences between right and left opisthomeres (
Figs. 8
d–e, g–h), ( 3 ) differences among individuals from the same vial (
Figs. 8
d–f), collecting locality or region (
Figs. 8
d–i). E.g. if we have a caudo-lateral view of the opisthomere (
Fig. 5
), the anterior process seems to be thinner, the posterior and postero-apical processes wider. However, if we change to antero-lateral view (
Fig. 7
), the opisthomere seems to have a wide anterior and a thin posterior process and the postero-apical process seems to be very thin. The first character combination describes
B. p. projectus
, the second fits for
B. p. dioritanus
. Therefore we concluded that
B. p. dioritanus
is not a valid subspecies. This problem of positioning has already been observed at the
Craspedosoma rawlinsii
-group, where 195 nominal taxa had been reduced to only 6 (
Hauser 2004
).

Individuals previously identified as
B. p. alticolus
showed the following characters: one intact male type specimen about 26 mm long, in stadium X. All other older males, in stadium XI, therefore longer, out of the proposed range of
B. p. alticolus
(which would be 25–28 mm for males (Verhoeff 1897 )). Shape of promere variable, sometimes like a
B. p. projectus
, or even tapering-like. The relative length of the two apical processes on the opisthomere was also variable, sometimes fitting the description of
B. p. alticolus
but long postero-apical processes were found, too. In addition, the within-population study provided individuals with even-length apical processes, while individuals in the same vials had long + short apical processes (
Figs. 8
d–e). Therefore we concluded that
B. p. alticolus
is not a valid subspecies, only an infrasubspecific category which has no standing in nomenclature (
ICZN 2000
).

The male specimen from Berchtesgaden, Germany , identified as
B. p. kochi
by Verhoeff seems to be a true
M. p. projectum
.

The external morphology of
M. projectum
vulvae was already represented in an early, little-known pioneer work by Sziráki ( 1966 ), while the inner structure was illustrated by Lazányi & Korsós (see
Fig. 7
in
Lazányi & Korsós 2010
).

We found a
M. p. projectum
female with elongated dorsal ampulla from the Aggtelek NP which lies on the distributional border of the two valid subspecies. An atypical male with intermediate-shaped promeres was also found in the ANP. The existence of intermediate forms in the overlapping distribution areas confirms the subspecies status of
M. p. projectum
and
M. p. kochi
.
